Review title: A terrific film which does the book justice...
Review_body: What a movie!!! I'm a huge fan of the book that the film is based on, the story is fantastic and one that has never been told in this way before. None of the books charisma and charm is lost with the transfer to the big screen, if anything it is amplified. First things first, cast: I don't think anyone at all is miscast in this film, if I had to say anyone was I would say maybe Emma Stone, but she does a good job in this film so you can forgive whatever qualms you have about her being cast as Skeeter. The rest of the cast is divine, it seems as though Tate Taylor assembled the greatest ensemble cast since the last Christopher Guest film. Octavia Spencer, Viola Davis, Allison Janney, Bryce Dallas Howard, Sissy Spacek and my personal favorite from the film, Jessica Chastain are all excellent, and all of them get to have their big moment, no one is left with nothing to do, all of them leave an impression.The adaptation is missing a few little details from the book, but it's OK, the bulk of the story gets across quite well. I think it will be a crime if Octavia, Viola and Jessica aren't mentioned when awards season rolls around. Miss Chastain being the standout for me, I hope she wins absolutely everything, Her character Celia was my favorite from the book and Miss Chastain is just electric in her portrayal as this wonderful character. I love her, she's just so great.This review is pretty bad but I just can't express in words how much I enjoyed it, just go see it and enjoy it for yourself.

Review title: "If you can love your enemy, you already have the victory."
Review_body: Stepping out of my usual comfort zone of movies I prefer, action flicks and Westerns, this one was an insightful look into an era in the country's history that is thankfully growing older by the day. It's disturbing to see how members of a minority race were treated at one time. Having grown up in the North, the racism wasn't as blatant, although I recall the 'n' word being used rather casually by adults when I was just a kid. Somehow that just never seemed right to me.The film has it's share of characters that one will immediately come to love and hate. Bryce Dallas Howard's Hilly Holbrook appeared to be the one most likely a caricature of all that was wrong with white employers of house servants during the Sixties South. Not that there couldn't have been real employers like her, but the portrayal in the movie was certainly meant to reflect the worst of the lot. One would also have to concur that what Skeeter Phelan's (Emma Stone) Mom (Allison Janney) did when firing her own maid (Cicely Tyson) was an act of despicable cruelty.The humanity of the black maids is wonderfully portrayed relative to the humor they saw in their daily lives amid some often times dreadful conditions. With a little more work, I think that 'eat my s...' scene could have gone down as one of the classics along side say, Meg Ryan's restaurant scene in "When Harry Met Sally". As it is, there was an awful lot of payback there for Hilly Holbrook's underhanded treatment of the housemaid.Octavia Spencer took a Best Supporting Actress for her role as Minny Jackson, well deserved though one can't help feel that the entire ensemble deserved as much, as recognized by the Screen Actors Guild. And though I've seen Jessica Chastain in other roles, this is the one that would put her in direct contention for portraying Marilyn Monroe should a project like that ever come along. Her resemblance and body language were uncanny.

Review title: Less like The Color Purple and more like Green Fried Tomatoes
Review_body: Sitting through "The Help" I was immediately entranced by the stellar performances of Viola Davis and Octavia Spencer as Aibileen Clark and Minny Jackson. Both carried the film with exceptional wit, warmth and strength that couldn't have been done by finer actresses. I recommend watching the movie for their performances alone. As the credits rolled and I started my drive home however, I began to reflect on the film and began to find some cracks in its veneer.The largest complaint shared by "The Help's" critics, myself included is its tone which at times becomes too light and airy. Indeed the filmmakers seem to gloss over showing the true nature of racism or for that matter the true nature of spousal abuse. The inherent graveness of a maid divulging information about their employer in 1960's Mississippi just isn't there, at least not to a realistic level.The film also stumbles on its portrayal of many of its white characters. Emma Stone's Skeeter is immediately sympathetic but shows little development or character flaws. Bryce Dallas Howard's Hilly is likewise one note and hollow. Her southern belle act and tactless racism becomes more of a caricature than a real person. It makes me wonder how Skeeter and Hilly could have ever been high school friends.For all "The Help's" faults however, there is no getting around the stellar performances from its two heroines. The story really is fascinating and the comic set-pieces achieve their goals. In fact I would say the film itself achieved its goals; my argument is they should have aimed higher.http://theyservepopcorninhell.blogspot.com/

Review title: wonderful film with great performances
Review_body: "The Help" is a film set in the 1960s just as the Civil Rights movement is taking off. Skeeter (Emma Stone) returns to her home town in Mississippi after college, desiring to become a writer. Shocked by the way some of the women treat their Afro-American maids, Skeeter decides to write a book from the viewpoint of the maids. Her family had a maid who basically raised her, Constantine (Cicely Tyson), but she's left the family, and Skeeter is unable to find out anything about why or what happened to her.The first housekeeper to open up is Aibileen (Viola Davis) and eventually more women join in. And it's quite a story they have to tell. Little do they know, they are on the cusp of the Civil Rights movement. Change is coming.The cast for this film is magnificent -- Bryce Dallas Howard is the nasty Hilly, Octavia Jackson plays a maid, Milly, who goes to work for Celia; Allison Janney is Skeeter's mother, Jessica Chastain is the heart-of-gold, rejected Celia, accused of breaking up a marriage. Every one of them creates a full character, and their acting is perfect. Both Howard and Stone step into a new category of acting expertise.Cicely Tyson has a few very small scenes, and she nearly steals the film. It's her performance that will haunt you.Also in the film are Sissy Spacek, Mary Steenburgen, Leslie Jordan, and Dana Ivey.This film will make you laugh, make you angry, and finally make you cry. It catches the '60s atmosphere and also the varying attitudes of the southern women, many of whom are bigoted and condescending.Unfortunately the racial problems in this country have yet to be solved. I remember one black woman and her husband going to Buffalo, New York, and being amazed that they could walk into any restaurant and not be thrown out. Another friend's father became ill while they were traveling in the south. They went to a clinic - because her father was of Sicilian descent and had been in the sun, he was cared for on the black side. Being from the north, they had no idea there was a black and white side.When you think about how many of these people had to live their lives, the restrictions they lived under, the lack of opportunity, it's sobering.Excellent film, thought-provoking, and highly recommended.
